1651615126867550209.text:
2/5 Redundant sentences guardrails: Remove redundant info from generated summaries

3/5 Extractive Summary: Fuzzy match over generated summary to find the source sentence to trace back the origins of each summary sentence!

4/5 Summary reading time: Self-explanatory

1651615128557875202.text:
5/5 Saliency check: Ensure that a key percentage of topics from the original documents are captured in the summary

‚öí How to use them ‚öí

Add the name of the guardrail to the RAIL spec:

E.g.

`<string name="summary" format="extractive-summary" />`

https://t.co/tNZJa8ez2D

1650883072324419587.text:
VERY excited to announce new comprehensive ‚ú®Text2SQL support‚ú® in @guardrails_ai!

What's new:
‚úÖ Create sandboxed db for testing
‚úÖ Validate SQL in sandbox
‚úÖ Constraints on predicates/columns
‚úÖ Reasking if any of ^^ fails
‚úÖ Few shot examples similar to query in prompt

(1/2) https://t.co/YIsnQgxQgx

1650943078566612993.text:
@ataiiam @guardrails_ai Thank you!

The sandboxed db is created once at the initialization of the Text2SQL module as an up front cost, and then reused for every LLM call.

1650892340054073345.text:
How to guard against prompt injection for Text2SQL use cases. Another one that's missing:

3. Always use a sandbox!

1643274020769394688.text:
The getting started guide now contains
step-by-step instructions about how to

‚úÖ add validation for quality criteria
‚úÖ specify corrective actions for when the LLM output is inavlid
‚úÖ inspect the logs to see how reasking works under the hood!

1642934899781910528.text:
If you're building an LLM application & the LLM occasionally produces garbage output, what do you do to correct it?

Here's how LLM mishaps are corrected in @guardrails_ai:

‚úÖ ReAsk: Automatically re-prompt LLM with helpful context & combine new response with previous ones
(1/n)

1642934900771766305.text:
‚úÖ Fix: Deterministically fix the garbage output, either by using a default value or by creating a programmatic fix
‚úÖ Filter: Filter out the specific invalid output from the full LLM response
‚úÖ Noop: Do nothing, but add to logs that some invalid output was generated
(2/n)

1642934901832859649.text:
‚úÖ Exception: Raise an exception.
‚úÖ Refrain: Sometimes, the output is so bad that the right thing to do is to refuse from returning any answer.

Read more about how to configure the correct action to take here https://t.co/qqOMNnPeVV

1642618722660798465.text:
üì£ @guardrails_ai now has a CLI!

You can use `guardrails validate` to validate your LLM outputs via the CLI. This unblocks using Guardrails from non-Python applications! üåü

Check out more details here https://t.co/j0uUWwc96F

Yess! Choice datatypes are pretty useful when you want to take an action, and want the LLM to specify details about that action.

E.g. pick ‚Äòfight‚Äô or ‚Äòflight‚Äô.

‚òëÔ∏èFor fight, choose a weapon (string)
‚òëÔ∏èFor flight, return a dictionary of direction and distance.

1640527225031389184.text:
Recorded my 5-min ‚ö°Ô∏è talk from AI Tinkerers' where I demoed @pydantic ü§ù @guardrails_ai!

Guardrails makes it really easy to ensure LLM-generated data is valid for a pydantic model. Under the hood, it reasks the LLM with new prompts until invalid data is corrected. Check it outüëá https://t.co/fdn4jWTL80

1640789918128701440.text:
It uses the pydantic model underneath! All of the validators that are defined in the pydantic model are executed, and reasking the LLM is triggered only when pydantic validation fails.

You can see the code for this example at 
https://t.co/G51JcP6Arl

üõ§Ô∏è New @guardrails_ai release out! `pip install guardrails-ai==0.1.3` for:

1636760559252131840.text:
üåü Support for ChatGPT(!!)

Add guardrails (i.e. output schema, validation and correction) to @OpenAI's ChatGPT API!

```
validated_output = guard(openai.ChatCompletion.create, model='gpt-3.5-turbo', ...)
```

1636760560279642115.text:
üåü Ability to configure max reasks *per query*

You can now set the maximum number of reasking LLMs to correct invalid output within the main guard call:

```
guard(openai.Completion.create, num_reasks=2, ...)
```

@alexchaomander Thank you! The full JSON object is returned from a single call to the LLM endpoint, so no extra cost than calling the LLM API directly!

The only caveat is if you've set 'reask' as a corrective action, in which case a 2nd call to the LLM API will be made to correct the answer

1631407520190447616.text:
Meerkat is awesome! If you‚Äôve ever felt the pain of trying to do data wrangling on unstructured data, you‚Äôll know that existing tools are severely lacking.

As with all ML/data science apps, you need to be able to see and feel your data for it to be useful

1631407521775906816.text:
Meerkat makes this ridiculously easy by closing the gap between backend data abstractions (i.e. dataframes) and interactive frontend components.

Have tested this out in the past, can‚Äôt wait to build more cool stuff with it üöÄ

Just goes to show the value of ML models-as-a-service!

Imagine a world where all ML model advances have an inference API that allows users to build cool apps like this. Takes away the burden of reproducibility from the user, and saves hours/$$ training a new model from scratch.

1635292891181621248.text:
At the heart of guardrails is RAIL, a language-agnostic spec that lets developers specify what a good LLM output looks like.

RAIL specifies structure + output validation, manages prompts and can contain custom code for validation, corrective action, etc.

https://t.co/iB55g8SNGa https://t.co/HEsw4bIRXT

1261111945215619072.text:
(1/2) I love this thread!

As an ML engineer in industry, a lot of my work is exploratory, so the tendency is to not merge code often. Isolating parts of your code that would be useful to your org (ie merge-able), is hard but rewarding. Code review is a great learning experience!

Guardrails adds a simple wrapper around your fave LLM API (e.g. OpenAI, ü§ó), and under the hood:

‚úÖ Appends output schema specification to your prompt
‚úÖ Checks that the LLM output adheres to structure & type specs (contd...)
